title-group.article-title: Synchronization and suppression of chaos in an electromagnetic system

abstract.p: In this study, various nonlinear dynamic analysis techniques are employed to reveal the rich nonlinear phenomena of an electromagnetic system. In particular, bifurcation diagrams, time responses, phase portraits, Poincare maps, power spectrum analysis, and the construction of basins of attraction are all powerful and effective tools for nonlinear dynamic problems. The Lyapunov exponent method is employed to show the occurrence of chaotic motion and to verify the numerical simulation results. Finally, two cases of a chaotic electromagnetic system being effectively controlled by a reference signal or being synchronized to another nonlinear electromagnetic system are presented.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
It is well known that the characteristics of magnetic bearings are inherently nonlinear due to the nonlinearities of electromagnetic forces. To accurately control or predict the performance of such a system, the effects of these nonlinearities must be taken into consideration. Therefore, in this author’s previous work (Chang and Tung, 1998), an experiment with a symmetric rotor with a spring device, as shown in Figure 1, was implemented by applying a series of nonlinear electromagnetic forces to identify a nonlinear model for the system. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of the electromagnetic system.

For convenient reference, the experimental results are presented in the previous work (Chang and Tung, 1998). These experimental results show the frequency responses of the rotor displacement for an input amplitude of 3.0 V in decreasing forcing frequency (ω) from 80 to 34.4 Hz. It can be seen that if the system starts at a high frequency and the forcing frequency is slowly decreased, there is an increase in amplitude along the resonant part of the response curve. The smooth variations in amplitude and frequency continue until ω = 37.6 Hz, where the first period-doubling bifurcation occurs. In this type of period-doubling bifurcation, a stable limit cycle loses its stability, while another closed orbit is born whose period is twice the period of the original oscillation. Beyond this point, the vibrating amplitude of the rotor and the coil current increase sharply. As the forcing frequency continues to decrease, the trajectory continues to experience period-doubling bifurcations, which eventually result in potentially chaotic motion. Finally, the rotor strikes the electromagnet, that is, the system explodes. This reaction indicates that the system exhibits complicated nonlinear behavior due to the nonlinearities of the electromagnetic force. In engineering applications, this characteristic should be taken into consideration at the design stage.

To study the dynamics of this system further, the conventional identification technique based on the principle of harmonic balance has been modified to identify this system. The resulting nonlinear model (Chang and Tung, 1998) is obtained as (1a)d2ydt2+b1dydt+b2y+b3y2+b4y3+b5(I0+i)6/3 +b6(I0+i)2/3+b7(I0+i)4/3+b0=0 (1b)L1(I0+i)-1didt+iR=KAA0sin(ωt) where I0 is the biased current calculated directly from the average experimental current time series, i is the oscillating current about I0 (=0.68 Amp), y is the oscillating displacement of the rotor about a reference point, R is the resistance of the coil, and KA (=2.254) is the power amplifier gain. This model successfully captures the primary characteristics of the system by comparing the frequency responses from simulations to those from experiments. However, theoretical analyses of this model showing whether the identified nonlinear mathematical model obtained from the experiment can predict and characterize the dynamics of the actual system have not yet been implemented. Furthermore, the occurrence of chaotic motion at the moment the rotor strikes the electromagnet has also not been investigated.

In this study, many numerical simulation methods have been employed to study the dynamic behavior of the system, such as bifurcation diagrams, time responses, Poincaré maps, and power spectrum analysis. The Lyapunov exponent method (Wolf et al., 1985) is also applied to show the occurrence of chaotic motion.

In many engineering problems concerning chaos control, it is important to develop control techniques to drive a chaotic attractor to a periodic orbit. Since the pioneering work of Ott et al. (1990) in controlling chaos, many modified methods and other approaches have successively been proposed (Ditto et al., 1990; Hunt, 1991; Lai et al., 1993; Fun and Tung, 1997; Cai et al., 2002a,b). As for the synchronization of chaos, many efforts have been made (Pecora and Carroll, 1990; Carroll and Pecora, 1991; John and Amritkar, 1994; Bai and Lonngren, 1999; Li and Tian, 2003). Usually, one chaotic system is referred to as the master (drive) system and the other as the slave (response) system. The basic idea of synchronization is to use the output of the master system to control the slave system so that the output of the slave system follows the output of the master system asymptotically. Some attempts to solve the problem have been made recently (Carroll and Pecora, 1991; Bai and Lonngren, 1999; Liao and Tsai, 2000). Finally, in this study, in order to improve the performance of a dynamic system or avoid the chaotic behavior, sometimes the chaotic behavior must be converted into a periodic motion. In this study, two methods are presented to control and suppress chaos: synchronization by a sinusoidal signal and synchronization by another nonlinear electromagnetic system.

sec.title: 2. Bifurcation diagrams and Lyapunov exponents
sec.p: The equations of motion were nondimensionalized in order to transform the system into the dimensionless domain, in which the behavior of different physical systems can conveniently be compared. The time t was nondimensionalized by using the electromagnetic system natural frequency (ωn). For convenience, first let ωn=b2, Ω=ω/ωn, τ=ωnt, x1=y, x2=y', and x3=i; normalize Equation (1) to a set of ordinary differential equations: (2a)x'1=x2, (2b)x'2=f(x1,x2,x3), (2c)x'3=(KAA0sin(Ωτ)-x3R)(I0+x3)L1ωn where f(x1,x2,x3)=-x1-(b1ωn)x2-(b3x12+b4x13+b5(I0+x3)6/3+b6(I0+x3)2/3+b7(I0+x3)4/3+b0)ωn

To clearly understand the characteristics of this system, a series of numerical simulations from Equation (2) is implemented. The commercial package DIVPRK of IMSL in FORTRAN subroutines for mathematics applications is used to solve the ordinary differential equations (IMSL Inc., 1989). The resulting bifurcation diagram is shown in Figure 2. It can be clearly seen from this figure that the first period-doubling bifurcation occurs at about Ω=1.863, and that at Ω=1.715 chaotic motion appears. More details about the various responses exhibited by the system are presented in Figure 3(a)–(h). There, each type of response is characterized by a Poincaré map and frequency spectrum. Figure 3(a) and (b) shows that the Tf-period mainly involves the constant term and the fundamental components. From Figure 3(c) and (d), it is observed that a cascade of period-doubling bifurcations causes a series of subharmonic components, which shows the bifurcations with new frequency components at Ω/2, 3Ω/2, 5Ω/2,…. The particular features of two descriptors characterize the essence of the chaotic behavior, that is, the Poincaré map and the frequency spectrum. The Poincaré map shows an infinite set of points referred to as a strange attractor. Simultaneously, the frequency spectrum of chaotic motion is a continuous broad spectrum. The two features – strange attractor and continuous-type Fourier spectrum – are strong indictors of chaos. The chaotic motions are shown in Figure 3(g) and (h). Figure 2.
Bifurcation diagram of the system for A0 = 3.0 V.
Figure 3.
Frequency spectra and Poincaré maps of various responses of numerical simulations for A0 = 3.0 V: (a) and (b) period-one motion, Ω = 1.95; (c) and (d) period-two motion, Ω = 1.80; (e) and (f) period-four motion, Ω = 1.7255; (g) and (h) chaotic motion, Ω = 1.708.

The occurrence of chaotic motion can be verified by means of Lyapunov exponent analysis. For every dynamic system, there is a spectrum of Lyapunov exponents (λ) (Wolf et al., 1985) that tells how length, areas, and volumes change in phase space. As a criterion for the existence of chaos, one needs only to calculate the largest exponent, which tells whether nearby trajectories diverge (λ > 0) or converge (λ < 0) on average. Any bounded motion in a system containing at least one positive Lyapunov exponent is defined as chaotic, while for periodic motion the Lyapunov exponents are not positive.

By referring to the algorithm for calculating the Lyapunov exponents described by Wolf et al. (1985), the evolution of the largest Lyapunov exponent for A0=3.0V is computed as displayed in Figure 4. From this figure, it is observed that the onset of chaotic motion is at Ω = 1.710, because at this point, P4, the largest Lyapunov exponent, changes its sign from negative to positive when the normalized forcing frequency is slowly decreased. For points P1–3, the largest Lyapunov exponents are shown to approach zero. The system at these points may undergo bifurcations. However, the Lyapunov exponent at such a point provides no means to determine the type of bifurcation; therefore, the bifurcation diagram presented in Figure 2 must be applied. For example, in Figure 2 the first period-doubling bifurcation occurs at about Ω = 1.860, while point P1, where the largest Lyapunov exponent first approaches zero, is found at Ω = 1.8475. Figure 4.
Largest Lyapunov exponents of the system for A0 = 3.0 V.

When the forcing frequency is larger than P1, Ω = 1.95; for example, the Lyapunov exponents computed from Equation (2) are λ1 = −0.082501, λ2 = −0.396172, and λ3 = −4.017426. Their sum is λ1 + λ2 + λ3 = −4.496099, which is negative, thus showing that the motion of the rotor at these values finally converges to a stable limit cycle. Indicating with λ1≥…≥λn the Lyapunov exponents of a dynamic system, Kaplan and Yorke (1979) provide an estimation for the Lyapunov dimension dL as (3)dL=j+1|λj+1|∑i=1jλi, where j is the largest integer that satisfies ∑i=1jλi>0. By applying the technique, the Lyapunov dimension of Equation (3) for Ω = 1.95 is dL = 1. Because the value of the Lyapunov dimension is an integer, the system has a periodic motion. When the forcing frequency decreases across the bifurcation point, for example Ω = 1.708, the Lyapunov exponents are λ1 = 0.1447, λ2 = −0.6234, and λ3 = −4.01773. Here, the Lyapunov dimension is dL = 2.232. It should be noted that the value of the Lyapunov dimension is not an integer; the system at this point can process fractal basin boundaries (Szemplińska-Stupnicka et. al., 1988), thus revealing that a measure of the fractal geometry of the attractor and the property of sensitivity dependence on initial conditions exist in the system. Figure 5 shows the fractal basin boundaries in such a case, with fixed A0 = 3.0 V, Ω = 1.708, and various initial conditions. For calculation (Tseng and Tung, 1995), 1600 × 250 sets of initial conditions were chosen in the form of a grid, and integration of Equation (2) using a fifth-order Runge–Kutta integration algorithm was continued until the system either converged to the bounded attractors or diverged. Initial conditions in the light regions lead to the divergent solutions, while the dark regions are the basins for the bounded attractors. The fractal structure indicates that small uncertainties in the initial conditions can lead to unpredictability of the system output. Figure 5.
Fractal basin boundaries of the system for A0 = 3.0 V at Ω = 1.708.

sec.title: 3. Synchronization and control of chaos
sec.p: From the Lyapunov exponents and the bifurcation diagram, one can clearly observe that the chaotic motion occurs at about Ω≤1.710. Now, the chaotic system considered in this study is given as follows: (4a)x'1=x2, (4b)x'2=f(x1,x2,x3)+u(τ), (4c)x'3=(KAA0sin(Ωτ)-x3R)(I0+x3)L1ωn, where f(x1,x2,x3) is a nonlinear function and u(τ) is the control signal that is to be designed. The main goal of the control is to determine u(τ) based on y~(τ), which is an arbitrarily given reference signal and its derivatives so that (5)|x1(τ)-y~(τ)|→0,asτ→∞.
Let α1 and α2 be any two positive constants and define (6)u(τ)=-f(x1,x2,x3)-α1x1-α2x2+(y~″+α2y~'+α1y~).
By substituting Equation (6) into Equation (4) obtain (7a)x'1=x2, (7b)x'2=-α1x1-α2x2+(y~″+α2y~'+α1y~), (7c)x'3=(KAA0sin(Ωτ)-x3R)(I0+x3)L1ωn, where α1 and α2 are the constant feedback gains.
The Jacobian matrix of the reduced linearized system about the equilibrium, x¯, is (8)J=[01-α1-α2].
The characteristic equation of J(x¯) is given by (9)λ2+α2λ+α1=0.
Using the Routh-Hurwiz criterion, it is easy to verify that the equilibrium, x¯, is locally asymptotically stable if and only if α1>0 and α2>0.
Below, a chaotic system controlled by a reference signal or synchronized to another nonlinear system is discussed (Bai and Lonngren, 1999).

sec.title: 3.1. Synchronization by a sinusoidal signal
sec.p:
The chaotic system for Equation (2) at Ω = 1.708 is considered. A control signal, u(τ), such as Equation (6) is adopted and the stability region in the α1 and α2 plane, as shown in Figure 6, is plotted. So, if the chaos is controlled to the period motion, then the choice of α1 and α2 should be taken from the stability region. On the other hand, the feedback gains α1 and α2 should be two positive constants, except from the empty region shown in Figure 6. After a time τ=150, as the values α1=1 and α2=1, the chaotic electromagnetic system will be synchronized with the sinusoidal signal: (10)y~(τ)=0.2sin(0.2τ). Figure 6.
Stability and unstability regions of the controlled system with a sinusoidal signal.

The synchronization errors, e1(τ)=x1(τ)-y~(τ) and e2(τ)=x2(τ)-y~'(τ), are shown in Figure 7. The time response of x1 is shown in Figure 8(a), where the control signal is added after τ=150. The chaotic system is controlled with the sinusoidal signal and converges into a period motion. The phase portrait of the controlled system is shown in Figure 8(b). Figure 7.
Synchronization errors via the controlled system with a sinusoidal signal.
Figure 8.
Injecting a sinusoidal signal control used to control the chaotic motion of the system for A0 = 3.0 V at Ω = 1.708. The sinusoidal signal is added after a time, τ=150: time response; (b) controlled orbit.

sec.title: 3.2. Synchronization by another nonlinear electromagnetic system
sec.p: The slave electromagnetic system given by the following equations is chosen: (11a)x'1=x2, (11b)x'2=f(x1,x2,x3)+u(τ), (11c)x'3=(KAA0sin(1.708τ)-x3R)(I0+x3)L1ωn.
The master electromagnetic system, where the forcing frequency in the slave system has been changed, is as follows: (12a)y'1=y2, (12b)y'2=f(y1,y2,y3), (12c)y'3=(KAA0sin(1.9τ)-y3R)(I0+y3)L1ωn.
According to Equation (6), the control signal, u(τ), is provided by (13)u(τ)=-f(x1,x2,x3)-α1x1-α2x2+(y″1+α2y'1+α1y1).

A control signal, u(τ), such as Equation (13), is adopted and the stability region in the α1 and α2 plane, as shown in Figure 9, is plotted. So, if the chaos is controlled to the period motion, then the choice of α1 and α2 should be taken from the stability region. In other words, the feedback gains α1 and α2 should be two positive constants, except from the empty region in Figure 9. After a time when τ=300, the chaotic electromagnetic system is synchronized by the control signal when α1=1 and α2=1. The synchronization errors, e1(τ)=x1(τ)-y1(τ) and e2(τ)=x2(τ)-y'1(τ), are shown in Figure 10. Figure 9.
Stability and instability regions of the controlled system with a reference signal generated by an electromagnetic system.
Figure 10.
Synchronization errors via the controlled system with a reference signal generated by an electromagnetic system.

The chaotic system is controlled with the sinusoidal signal and converges into a period motion. The control signal is added after τ=300. The time response of x1 is shown in Figure 11(a); the phase portrait of the controlled system is shown in Figure 11(b). Figure 11.
Injecting a reference signal generated by an electromagnetic system used to control the chaotic motion of the system for A0 = 3.0 V at Ω = 1.708. The control signal is added after a time, τ=150: (a) time response; (b) controlled orbit.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: The nonlinear response characteristics of an electromagnetic system have been studied in order to reveal the nonlinear dynamic behavior, which has been displayed in bifurcation diagrams. In this report, many numerical simulation methods have been employed to study the dynamic behavior of the system. An interpretation of the periodic and chaotic motion has been offered, based on time responses, phase portraits, Poincaré maps, and power spectrum analysis. Furthermore, the chaotic motion has been detected by using Lyapunov exponents and Lyapunov dimensions effectively.

The presence of chaotic behavior is typical for certain nonlinearities, ranges of parameters, and external force, where one wishes to avoid or control so as to improve the performance of a dynamic system. Two cases of a chaotic electromagnetic system being successfully controlled by a reference signal or being synchronized to another electromagnetic system have been presented. Thus, one can also efficiently suppress chaos and convert the chaotic system into a periodic orbit. Finally, the stability and instability regions of the controlled system in the control parameter space, α1 and α2, have been found.
